ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Challenges, ethics, and strategies of conflict reporting
Learned a lot about the methods of journalism and how these techniques can influence and be influenced by conflicts.

I learned a lot about the media world with relation to conflict reporting. The class also covered numerous topics such as Iraq War, Israel-Palestine, Vietnam war etc. I learned a lot and read a lot of amazing articles and books.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: It is interesting to see how the readings place past U.S. military interventions into the context of contemporary public opinion. 
Weaknesses: The discussion often lost momentum and veered off track. I think the fact that almost all of our readings were newspaper or magazine articles also made the expectations for our papers a little ambiguous.

Strengths: the readings are incredibly interesting and the professor is fabulous. 

This is not really a weakness but often the discussions focused on big topic that wasnt always super relevant to the readings but this made for really great discussions and insights.

It is a great course. The readings are amazing and a nice break from classes with heavy empirical/research type readings. Some weeks were heavier in terms of workload with page numbers but still way easier to read than most other classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really appreciated the in-person meeting with Professor Wood.
I really enjoyed the format and thought it was successful even on Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the Media and Conflict class tackles the difficult ethical questions of conflict journalism very well and provokes questions to reflect on for those hoping to dive into the profession in the future.
I would recommend this course to those who are very interested in conflict reporting and knowledgeable about the history of U.S. military intervention.
Yes! Excellent readings and interesting speakers!
Absolutely 100% this was one of my favorite classes at Yale.
Yes! You will never see reporting (especially on wars and foreign affairs) the same way again.

Absolutely take this class if looking for a good and interesting PLSC seminar. Professor is phenomenal and during COVID at least we were able to get a lot of fantastic speakers to come discuss and talk with us. Great class!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Those in New Haven had one in-person meeting with Professor Wood instead of a virtual seminar.
